      "total_count": 1,

```

title: Add `internal` as valid Repository visibility value
body:
Issue:

- PyGithub currently throws an `AssertionError` when attempting to create or edit a Repository where param `visibility="internal"`.
- This is an issue because `"internal"` is a valid Repository visibility value for GitHub Enterprise users.
- [https://docs.github.com/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/rest/repos/repos?apiVersion=2022-11-28#create-an-organization-repository](https://docs.github.com/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/rest/repos/repos?apiVersion=2022-11-28#create-an-organization-repository)

Example of the issue:

```python
org = gh.get_organization(organization)
org.create_repo(name="test-repo", visibility="internal")
# throws AssertionError and fails to create repo
```

Proposed fix (in pull request): 

- Allow `"internal"` as a valid value for `visibility`

Example:

```python
org = gh.get_organization(organization)
org.create_repo(name="test-repo", visibility="internal")
# does not throw assertion error and successfully creates repo
```

title: Organization.name gives None
body:
**Issue:** Instances of class pygithub.Organization has value `None` for property `name`

For the code,
```py
from github import Github

gh = Github(gh_token)
gh_organization = gh.get_organization("MY_GH_ORG")

print(gh_organization.name)
```

Actual Output is,
```sh
None
```

Expected Output should be,
```sh
MY_GH_ORG
```

PyGithub version used: 1.59.0

body: Version 2.1.0 introduced a breaking change to the `Repository.create_pull` method. This PR updates the example provided in the docs: https://pygithub.readthedocs.io/en/latest/examples/PullRequest.html#create-a-new-pull-request

title: Feature Request- Request to support pull request reviews
body:
## Request to add functionality to perform actions on pull request reviews - Feature Request
I can see there is API published by Github to be able to work with reviews for a pull request (LIST, GET, POST etc).
It would be great if that functionality can be supported within PyGithub as well.

Here is [link](https://docs.github.com/en/rest/pulls/reviews?apiVersion=2022-11-28#create-a-review-for-a-pull-request) to Github APIs.

title: Incomplete API documentation on stable PyGithub
body:
I'm trying to update my code with the latest PyGithub classes however documentation is missing on the new authentication methods.

jwt – string deprecated, use auth=github.Auth.AppAuth(…) or auth=github.Auth.AppAuthToken(…) instead

AppAuthToken
AppInstallationAuth

Parameters have also been ordered according to the REST API order in the documentation

Tested in the repl:

```
>>> from github import Auth, Github
>>> import os
>>> key = os.environ.get("GITHUB_ACCESS_TOKEN")
>>> auth = Auth.Token(key)
>>> g = Github(auth=auth)
>>> repo = g.get_repo("PyGithub/PyGithub")
>>> res = repo.get_pulls(state="all", per_page=100, page=2)
>>> for p in res:

...

title: Fix the Pip install command
body:
On the front page of the [README Install](https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub#install) Instructions there is a button to copy  `$ pip install PyGithub` command to the clipboard
Due to the leading `$` this command fails when pasted into a terminal
Removing the leading `$` from the command so it can be copy pasted

title: Close connections after use
body:
Currently connections are closed once `Github` instance is GC, this change introduces a way to explicitly close connections and with a context manager for MainClass. Also makes `Requester` thread safe when creating new connections concurrently.

Usages:

```python
   with Github(auth=auth) as g:
     # do something
```

or

```python
    g = Github(auth=auth)
    # do something
    g.close()
```


Fix #1859

```

orgs = Github(auth=auth).get_user().get_orgs()
```

title: Add `license` attribute to `Repository`
body:
The GitHub API behind `.get_repo()` also delivers licensing information, but PyGithub doesn't pick it up. This Pull Request changes that.

It extracts the SPDX license ID, IMHO the most important information which is provided and with which a user can get more information (like the license text or full name).

This is my first contribution ot the project and I hope it meets your requirements.

AsertionError: True

title: Search Workflows by Name
body:
The existing `get_workflow()` method only works with the input of a workflow ID or workflow filename. This pull request (PR) serves to elevate the method's functionality by enabling the utilization of workflow names as an alternative approach to identifying the relevant workflow.

```
>>> repo.get_workflow(2008038)
Workflow(url="https://api.github.com/repos/PyGithub/PyGithub/actions/workflows/2008038", name="Publish to PyPI")
>>> repo.get_workflow("2008038")
Workflow(url="https://api.github.com/repos/PyGithub/PyGithub/actions/workflows/2008038", name="Publish to PyPI")
>>> repo.get_workflow("Publish to PyPI")
Workflow(url="https://api.github.com/repos/PyGithub/PyGithub/actions/workflows/2008038", name="Publish to PyPI")
```

title: WorkflowStep.conclusion says "success" but the step has failed with exit code 1.
body: Sadly, there is no way to verify if the individual step failed or not. The conclusion variable should be used for that. But that is not true. The step returned non zero exit code but still the conclusion variable says "success".

title: Removing use of .netrc from default behaviour.
body:
While attempting to use PyGitHub, I noticed that it would ignore the given credentials and always used my machine's .netrc credentials.

This PR adds an assert to ensure that at least one login method is provided, and ensures that the provided login method is used (via the method proposed in PR #910).

If using a .netrc file is desired as a fallback, the assert could be removed. If that is the case, a flag could be added to the constructor or the documentation updated to explain this.

## Expected Behaviour:

```
User@Computer:~$ python3
Python 3.11
>>> from github import Auth, Github
>>> gh = Github()
>>> print("Using user account {}".format(gh.get_user().login))
Traceback (most recent call last):
    (...)
  File "/home/user/.local/lib/python3.11/site-packages/github/Requester.py", line 487, in __check
    raise self.__createException(status, responseHeaders, data)
github.GithubException.GithubException: 401 {"message": "Requires authentication", "documentation_url": "https://docs.github.com/rest/users/users#get-the-authenticated-user"}
>>>
```

## Actual Behaviour:

```
User@Computer:~$ python3
Python 3.11
>>> from github import Auth, Github
>>> gh = Github()
>>> print("Using user account {}".format(gh.get_user().login))
Using user account DanielNaaykens
>>>
```

## New Behaviour:

```
User@Computer:~$ python3
Python 3.11
>>> from github import Auth, Github
>>> gh = Github()
>>> print("Using user account {}".format(gh.get_user().login))
Traceback (most recent call last):
    (...)
  File "/home/user/.local/lib/python3.11/site-packages/github/MainClass.py", line 139, in __init__
    assert (
AssertionError: At least one authorization method is required.
>>>
```

title: Provide versioned docs in readthedocs.io
body:
1.59 is a month old and already the 1.58 docs are gone from readthedocs.  While I understand you consider 1.59 stable, there are many distribution managed installations out there where 1.58.2 is still the latest available package.

Yes, I'm aware I could create a virtualenv and pip install a non-managed package, but that doesn't really excuse blowing away document ion that's _still relevant_.

title: fix: allow app installation to use custom certificate authority file
body:
Pass the `verify` value from the requester, or it will default to `True`.

<details>
<summary>Minimal code example and explanation</summary>

Assume I have a `ca.pem` for my company, and it won't be able to verify `api.github.com`

```python
auth = Auth.AppAuth(
    app_id,
    private_key,
).get_installation_auth(installation_id)

Github(auth=auth, verify="ca.pem")

# expect a blow up
print(auth.token)
```

It does not blow up, because at the time of evaluation, `verify=True`, and the default CA (which can validate `api.github.com`) is used instead. Why?

It turns out that `verify` was not being passed into the `GithubIntegration` (a couple of layers down in the call stack).
</details>

The following python code:

def mark_duplicates(git_repo_url: str, git_pat_token: str):
    github_logged_in: Github = Github(git_pat_token)
    owner, repo = get_owner_and_repo(git_repo_url)
    repo = github_logged_in.get_repo(owner, repo)
    repo_issues: Github.PaginatedList.PaginatedList = repo.get_issues(state="open")
  
    for issue in repo_issues:
        # ERROR HERE
        print(issue)
```

Results in the following error:

```
dup_hawk/dup_hawk.py:37: in mark_duplicates
    for issue in repo_issues:
.venv/lib/python3.10/site-packages/github/PaginatedList.py:69: in __iter__
    newElements = self._grow()
.venv/lib/python3.10/site-packages/github/PaginatedList.py:80: in _grow
    newElements = self._fetchNextPage()
.venv/lib/python3.10/site-packages/github/PaginatedList.py:213: in _fetchNextPage
    headers, data = self.__requester.requestJsonAndCheck(

>           raise self.__createException(status, responseHeaders, data)

title: total count showing 0 when list has values
body:
I am running PyGithub==1.59.0 and when I am using totalCount, I am getting a value of 0 when there are values in the paginated list. When I iterate through the list with a for loop I get a count from the list. I am connecting to GitHub Enterprise Server 3.7.9. Though when I tested the same code on github.com I got a similar experience. Thank you. 

Personal Access token has scopes read:enterprise, read:org, read:user, repo:invite, repo:status, repo_deployment, user:email

With the POC below I am seeing a value of 0 for total_count, but see 399 for manual_counter. Are there any known issues with PyGithub and GHE? 

```
from github import Auth, Github
auth = Auth.Token(PAT_HERE)
g = Github(auth=auth, base_url="https://COMPANY_GHE_HOSTNAME/api/v3")
orgs = g.get_organizations()

total_count = orgs.totalCount

manual_counter = 0

for org in orgs:
    manual_counter+=1

print("Manual for loop counter {}".format(manual_counter))
print("Total count method  {}".format(total_count))

title: Use timezone-aware reset datetime in GithubRetry.py
body:
`reset` and the current datetime used to compute the time delta after which retry should happen were timezone-unaware and timezone-aware respectively, resulting in 

`TypeError: can't subtract offset-naive and offset-aware datetimes` being thrown.

This PR changes `datetime.utcfromtimestamp(int)` to `datetime.fromtimestamp(int, timezone.utc)` making both `reset` and current datetimes timezone-aware.

Tests have been updated to reflect that.

title: Test on Windows and macOS, don't fail fast
body:
The `Test success` check aggregates all test jobs outcome and allows to require a single check. Then we can modify job names and configure final CI success through workflow file and not repo settings.

This requires removing `CI/test (Python x.y)` as required checks and adding `test success` instead.

This would have discovered #2587 before merge.

title: Mypy errors on some exception in 1.59.0
body:
After upgrading to 1.59.0 we got a mypy error on our code catching `UnknownObjectException`:

```
    except github.UnknownObjectException as err:
        message = err.data['message']
```

Now mypy is raising:
```
error: Invalid index type "str" for "str | dict[str, str | list[str] | list[dict[str, str]]]"; expected type "SupportsIndex | slice"  [index]
```

This seems to be caused by the improved type annotation of the `GithubException` base class introduced in #2463:

```
    @property
    def data(
        self,
    ) -> Union[str, Dict[str, Union[str, List[str], List[Dict[str, str]]]]]:
```
Also declared in the `__init__()` signature.

AFAIK `UnknownObjectException` is only raised by `Requester.py` always returning `data` as `output: Dict[str, Any]` so `UnknownObjectException` could be updated to clarify this more accurately so that mypy will not raise typing errors that cannot occur at runtime.

title: Installation not found - github.GithubException.UnknownObjectException: 404
body:
My GitHub app creates a workflow, when installed on an account. I want to delete that same workflow, when the app is uninstalled. So the webhook event is installation with action deleted. 

My PyGitHub version is 1.59.0. The issue seems to be with the line 
**installation = gi.get_app_installation(installation_id)** 

```
auth = github.Auth.AppAuth(app_id, app_key)
gi = github.GithubIntegration(auth=auth)

def handle_webhooks():
    event_type = request.headers.get("X-GitHub-Event")
    payload = request.json
        ...
        if event_type == "installation" and payload["action"] == "deleted":
            installation_id = payload["installation"]["id"]
            installation = gi.get_app_installation(installation_id)
```

although the same kind of authentication works fine, when creating and committing the workflow, meaning that this function: 

```
def create_workflow():
    installation_id = request.json.get("installationId")
    installation = gi.get_app_installation(installation_id)
    workflow_content = "..."
    for repo in installation.get_repos():
        new_file = repo.create_file(
            path=".github/workflows/my-workflow.yml",
            message="Add workflow file",
            content=workflow_content,
            branch="main"
        )
```
works as expected. 

I can provide full error message, if needed.

title: Calling `Branch.edit_protection` fails when any `required_pull_request_reviews` field set
body:
<strike>It seems that the signature for `Branch.edit_protection` differs in the `.pyi` and `.py` file. In the [`.pyi`](https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/094538e10c1da6f3bbd31ea1f2d102e48e3649c5/github/Branch.pyi#L38) file the arguments are called `user_bypass_pull_request_allowances`, `team_bypass_pull_request_allowances` and `app_bypass_pull_request_allowances` (not the leading singular) whereas in the [.py`](https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/094538e10c1da6f3bbd31ea1f2d102e48e3649c5/github/Branch.py#L131C4-L131C4) file the arguments are plural (`users_bypass_pull_request_allowances`, `teams_bypass_pull_request_allowances` and `apps_bypass_pull_request_allowances`)</strike> fixed in #2571.

There also seems to be a problem where passing nothing for `user_bypass_pull_request_allowances` results in an error when `require_code_owner_reviews` or `dismiss_stale_reviews` are given:

```
github.GithubException.GithubException: 422 {"message": "Invalid request.\n\nNo subschema in \"anyOf\" matched.\nFor 'properties/bypass_pull_request_allowances', nil is not an object.\nNot all subschemas of \"allOf\" matched.\nFor 'anyOf/1', {\"dismiss_stale_reviews\"=>true, \"require_code_owner_reviews\"=>true, \"bypass_pull_request_allowances\"=>nil} is not a null.", "documentation_url": "https://docs.github.com/rest/branches/branch-protection#update-branch-protection"}
```

https://docs.github.com/en/rest/branches/branch-protection?apiVersion=2022-11-28#update-branch-protection

title: Repository.size is not returning a correct/useful value
body:
The Repository class has an attribute called "size." However, this attribute seems to return values that have nothing to do with the size of the repository. 

For example, the repository "papasinku/fp2MBtest" is 2076703 bytes in size, but the value returned by the ".size" attribute is 3!

```Python
assert github.Github().get_repo("papasinku/fp2MBtest").size == 2076703 # fails because returned value is 3
```

title: Make datetime objects timezone-aware
body:
Continues #1831.

> Timestamps returned by the GitHub API include timezone information, yet PyGithub throws this information away. This can lead to wrong results in client code, as naïve timestamps are generally assumed to use the system time zone, yet the majority of timestamps returned by the API are in UTC. This PR fixes the library to retain timezone information when parsing timestamps and always produce timezone-aware datetime objects.

Additionally, this imports `date, datetime, timezone` directly and reduces code like `datetime(…, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)` to `datetime(…, tzinfo=timezone.utc))`.

This also replaces some `datetime.timezone(datetime.timedelta(0))` with `timezone.utc`.

Fixes #512.

Here is the context and what I do to reproduce:

        headers, data = self.__requester.requestJsonAndCheck("GET", url)

title: Link to stable docs, update introduction in package used by pypi, move auth arg front
body:
Pypi and README.md link to the latest docs, which is confusing, as it might include non-released code: #2550

This changes links to stable docs, which are least surprising.

Also Updates example in `setup.py`, that is used by Pypi, which is not up-to-date with docs.

title: Rework GithubIntegration
body:
Both `github.Github` and `github.GithubIntegration` are main entry points of this library. They create a `Requester` instance that handles all requests to the Github REST API. Requester has numerous arguments like `base_url` or `timeout`.

Firstly, `Github` and `GithubIntegration` should support the same (full) set of `Requester` arguments.

Secondly, creating a `Github` instance for a Github App Installation coming from `GithubIntegration` should use the same `Requester` arguments (except for `auth`). It should suffice to define `base_url` and other parameters once.

Fixes issues like #2455.

The rate limit changes after a call to `totalCount`.

```python
client = Github("TOKEN")
commits = client.search_commits(query = 'author:LucBerge')

commits.totalCount
print(client.rate_limiting)
```

I know the [rate limit changes if the user is authenticated or not.](https://docs.github.com/en/rest/overview/resources-in-the-rest-api?apiVersion=2022-11-28#rate-limiting) Could it be related ?

Maybe the call to `totalCount` unauthentify the client (remove the token) ?

title: Implement `AppUserAuth` for Github App user tokens
body: Allows to refresh Github App user token. Integrates `ApplicationOAuth` into `github.Auth`.

title: Add sort order and direction for getting comments
body:
Some methods getting comments miss sort query parameters.

Note: This is a breaking change. The order of parameters of `PullRequest.get_review_comments` has changed to match other `get_comments` methods and Github API parameter order. Users should change `PullRequest.get_review_comments(since)`  to `PullRequest.get_review_comments(since=since)`.

Calling without parameter is not breaking: `PullRequest.get_review_comments()`

title: Fix `Branch.bypass_pull_request_allowances` failing with "nil is not an object"
body:
message:

    Invalid request.

    No subschema in "anyOf" matched.
    For 'properties/bypass_pull_request_allowances', nil is not an object.
    Not all subschemas of "allOf" matched.
    For 'anyOf/1', {"required_approving_review_count"=>1, "bypass_pull_request_allowances"=>nil} is not a null.

documentation_url:

https://docs.github.com/rest/branches/branch-protection#update-branch-protection

Fix by not adding the bypass_pull_request_allowances object at all if not needed. This is similar to the dismissal_restrictions logic.

Fixes #2578.

body: https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/issues/2523

title: Update docstring and typing for allow_forking and allow_update_branch (Repository)
body: The Repository interface was behind the function itself and would not allow a couple of the options to be used.  This PR brings them inline.

title: Add authentication classes, move auth logic there
body:
Reduces complexity from Requester and moves lots of auth-specific logic into `Auth` implementations.

Fixes #2431.

Allows for easy fix of #2471 and #2504: https://github.com/EnricoMi/PyGithub/pull/4.

Fixes bad code like

https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/b94a83cbf328bbcdabeaaaef572d5ca360e1dbba/github/ApplicationOAuth.py#L94

https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/pull/2528/files#diff-e1bc4144bb47d4a87072d8149e91f8c66463d81346d958b6f5d3d7dcd9f33375

This is backward compatible to existing auth arguments.

title: Occational not found on `get_repo` API
body:
I'm not sure how to reproduce, but it happen sometimes.

I didn't inspect the detail code so this is just my doubt: Does PyGithub have retry logic? If not, would it be possible to fail the request when the network instantly disconnected?

requests.exceptions.SSLError: HTTPSConnectionPool(host='api.github.com', port=443): Max retries exceeded with url: /repos/Glimpse/xxx (Caused by SSLError(SSLEOFError(8, 'EOF occurred in violation of protocol (_ssl.c:1131)')))

i have tried to set the retry parameter in 2 ways below,but it seem didn't work

g1 = Github(access_token1,retry=Retry(100))
g1 = Github(access_token1,retry=100)

title: Merging 1.58.x patch release notes into master
body: The fixes are already contained in master, only the `changes.rst` are missing.

title: Raise error on unsupported redirects, log supported redirects
body:
Redirects that do not change the url path but other pieces like host name or protocol schema end up in an endless loop because only the path part of the new location is redirected to: https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/issues/2447#issuecomment-1539048322

This identifies situations where hostname, protocol or port number change in a redirect. Instead of redirecting to the new location, an error is raised because the base url should be corrected. Otherwise, each request will be redirected, duplicating the traffic and calls.

Further, any redirection is logged to info level. There have been many issues where knowing a redirect happened (without enabling debug level) would have helped investigating and understanding.

title: Updating Settings of Repositories-Limited options
body:
Hello, I am writing a script to update the settings of repositories with common required settings. I face some limitations when I use the available methods for the settings.
For example, I am using the edit method from the Repository class which calls the endpoint [PATCH /repos/{owner}/{repo} but only limited settings can be updated by using this method while through the endpoint all of the settings can be changed.
I wanted to ask if the rest of the options will be added to the code.
![edit_method](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/115500459/236939992-7e0452e2-cfdf-46b6-b5a8-21c894f82949.png)
@nkakouros

title: PullRequest create_comment to support new changes
body:
Seems like PullRequest `create_comment` (`create_review_comment`) is outdated according to https://docs.github.com/en/rest/pulls/comments?apiVersion=2022-11-28#create-a-review-comment-for-a-pull-request (for instance, the `subject_type` option or `position` -> `line`)

I can open a PR from my forked version--looking to see if it's relevant or someone is already working on it.

body: Fixes #2456.

body:
repo.get_contents("", ref=branch) is not getting the correct branch contents
instead, it's still get the default branch contents.

title: Add missing attributes to Branch
body:
Hi!

We added a bunch of missing attributes missing in `Branch.py` that are needed for a project we own.

I tried my best to follow the [CONTRIBUTING.md](https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md) guide but I was not able to follow the [Adding missing attributes for a GithubObject](https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#adding-missing-attributes-for-a-githubobject) section because I wanted to keep a consistent API with the existing one.

Let me know if there is something missing in the PR to accept this one.

This PR supersedes #2449 and solves #2448 and #2486

title: Max retries exceeded with url
body:
Hello,

When running the below code,
```
from github import Github

g = Github(githubToken) #ghp_xxxxx
repo = g.get_repo(githubRepo)
query = repo.get_contents(cfg.Github["QueryPath"], cfg.Github["Branch"])
self.testQuery = encodedOnboardingQuery.decoded_content.decode("utf-8")
```
I run into this error

`Type: <class 'requests.exceptions.ConnectTimeout'>, Value: HTTPSConnectionPool(host='[api.github.com](http://api.github.com/)', port=443): Max retries exceeded with url: /repos/abcd/xxxx (Caused by ConnectTimeoutError(<urllib3.connection.HTTPSConnection object at 0x7f75390c04d0>, 'Connection to [api.github.com](http://api.github.com/) timed out. (connect timeout=15)')).`

1. Is this a rate limit issue or something else?
2. If I need to add retry logic, how do I do that

Thank You.

title: Add Webhook Deliveries
body:
### Webhook Deliveries

Add support for Organization and Repository Webhook Deliveries

#### Summary of Changes

- Added two methods to MainClass, Organization, and Repository to support `get_hook_delivery` and `get_hook_deliveries`
- Created a `HookDelivery` model where `github.HookDelivery.HookDelivery` is a subclass of `github.HookDelivery.HookDeliverySummary` for DRY implementation
- Added test cases to Organization and Repository for validation

Resolves #2507

title: ENHANCEMENT: Support for Webhook Deliveries
body:
I have looked through the documentation and code base as well as exisiting/closed issues, and can not seem to find any reference to webhook deliveries.  Apologies if I overlooked it, but would it would be great if webhook deliveries could be supported.

References:
[Organization Webhook Deliveries](https://docs.github.com/en/rest/orgs/webhooks?apiVersion=2022-11-28#list-deliveries-for-an-organization-webhook)

[Repository Webhook Deliveries](https://docs.github.com/en/rest/webhooks/repo-deliveries?apiVersion=2022-11-28#list-deliveries-for-a-repository-webhook)

title: Version 1.58.2
body: This collects issues and fixes for bugs to be released with v1.58.2.

title: Installation.get_repos() appears to be broken - always throws BadCredentialsException
body:
Is there anyone using this method? The only other reference to my issue is two comments in this stale pull request #1791 which seems to agree with my findings. Alternatively, we are both guilty of user error.

To recreate the issue:
1) Create a github app with read access to repositories.
2) Install it in your user account granting access to all repositories, or at least one private repo used for this example.
3) Create and download an application private key ".pem" file.
4) Note the application ID.

Initialize the integration and installation. Ensure that the installation credentials work for mundane requests (get repo).
```
$ python3
Python 3.11.2 (main, Feb 16 2023, 03:07:35) [Clang 14.0.0 (clang-1400.0.29.202)] on darwin
>> from github import *
>> with open("mykeyfile.pem", "r") as f:
...  private_key = f.read().strip()

>> app_id = "123456" // use your application id.
>> integration = github.GithubIntegration(app_id, private_key)
>> installation = integration.get_repo_installation('myuser', 'my-private-repo')
>> token = integration.get_access_token(installation.id).token
>> g = Github(token)
>> g.get_repo('myuser/my-private-repo')
Repository(full_name="myuser/my-private-repo")
```

The failure

```
>> print('Using the same installation, I get this failure')
>> installation.get_repos()
<github.PaginatedList.PaginatedList object at 0x11248d450>
>>> hitting_the_api_now = [r for r in installation.get_repos()]
File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <listcomp>
  File "/users/Ubuntu/test_error/.venv/lib/python3.11/site-packages/github/PaginatedList.py", line 56, in __iter__
    newElements = self._grow()
                  ^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "/users/Ubuntu/test_error/.venv/lib/python3.11/site-packages/github/PaginatedList.py", line 67, in _grow
    newElements = self._fetchNextPage()
                  ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "/users/Ubuntu/test_error/.venv/lib/python3.11/site-packages/github/PaginatedList.py", line 201, in _fetchNextPage
    headers, data = self.__requester.requestJsonAndCheck(
                    ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "/users/Ubuntu/test_error/.venv/lib/python3.11/site-packages/github/Requester.py", line 398, in requestJsonAndCheck
    return self.__check(
           ^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "/users/Ubuntu/test_error/.venv/lib/python3.11/site-packages/github/Requester.py", line 423, in __check
    raise self.__createException(status, responseHeaders, output)
github.GithubException.BadCredentialsException: 401 {"message": "Bad credentials", "documentation_url": "https://docs.github.com/rest"}
```

title: Add type stub for get_project_column
body: `get_project_column` was missing from the type stubs, so both mypy and pyright complained when using the method.

title: Failed to create a pr review comment
body:
hi
I am trying to create pr review comments but getting this error:

```python
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/action_internal/main.py", line 173, in <module>
    main()
  File "/action_internal/main.py", line 169, in main
    send_code_comments(repo_token, after_sha, repo_name, int(issue_number), lines)
  File "/action_internal/comment.py", line 35, in send_code_comments
    pr.create_review_comment(
  File "/usr/lib/python3.10/site-packages/github/PullRequest.py", line 431, in create_review_comment
    headers, data = self._requester.requestJsonAndCheck(
  File "/usr/lib/python3.10/site-packages/github/Requester.py", line 398, in requestJsonAndCheck
    return self.__check(
  File "/usr/lib/python3.10/site-packages/github/Requester.py", line 423, in __check
    raise self.__createException(status, responseHeaders, output)
github.GithubException.GithubException: 422 {"message": "Validation Failed", "errors": [{"resource": "PullRequestReviewComment", "code": "custom", "field": "pull_request_review_thread.end_commit_oid", "message": "pull_request_review_thread.end_commit_oid is not part of the pull request"}, {"resource": "PullRequestReviewComment", "code": "missing_field", "field": "pull_request_review_thread.diff_hunk"}], "documentation_url": "https://docs.github.com/rest/reference/pulls#create-a-review-comment-for-a-pull-request"}
```

It seems that some object defs were out-of-dated.

https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/300c5015d41236eb410b9cbe895258294e3500af/github/PullRequest.py#L425

```python
post_parameters = {
            "body": body,
            "commit_id": commit_id._identity,
            "path": path,
            "position": position,
        }
```

https://docs.github.com/en/rest/pulls/comments?apiVersion=2022-11-28#create-a-review-comment-for-a-pull-request

The official doc said `position` is deprecated. Use line instead.

Leverage PEP 484 inline types instead of `.pyi` files
body:
[PEP 484](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0484/) support was added in Python 3.5, and this library supports 3.7+, as such the `.pyi` files are now redundant and types can be included in line directly in the source files.

I'd like to propose that new classes use [PEP 484](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0484/), and old classes are slowly migrated to use [PEP 484](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0484/) over time.

Thoughts?

title: from github import Github ERROR CODE
Add allow_auto_merge support to Repository
body:
Closes #2476 

Adds `allow_auto_merge` attribute to a Repository: https://docs.github.com/en/rest/repos/repos#update-a-repository

> `allow_auto_merge` boolean
> Either `true` to allow auto-merge on pull requests, or `false` to disallow auto-merge.

This attribute can be modified via edit (on a private repository):

```
>>> g.get_repo("<test repo>").allow_auto_merge
True
>>> g.get_repo("<test repo>").edit(allow_auto_merge=False)
>>> g.get_repo("<test repo>").allow_auto_merge
False
>>> g.get_repo("<test repo>").edit(allow_auto_merge=True)
>>> g.get_repo("<test repo>").allow_auto_merge
True
```

body:

> `allow_auto_merge` boolean
> Either `true` to allow auto-merge on pull requests, or `false` to disallow auto-merge.

This attribute can be modified via edit (on a private repository):

```
>>> g.get_repo("<test repo>").allow_auto_merge
True
>>> g.get_repo("<test repo>").edit(allow_auto_merge=False)
>>> g.get_repo("<test repo>").allow_auto_merge
False
>>> g.get_repo("<test repo>").edit(allow_auto_merge=True)

True
```

title: Add clone_to() method for cloning repositories
body:
Currently, the PyGithub library does not provide a method for cloning a repository to a local directory. This feature would be useful for a variety of use cases, such as automated backups, data processing, or testing.

The `clone_to()` method would allow users to clone a repository to a local directory using the GitHub API, without requiring the use of the `git` command line tool. This method would simplify the process of cloning a repository and make it more accessible to users who are not familiar with `git`.

It is important to note that the `clone_to()` method should be designed to run in a single-threaded environment since Cloud functions do not support multiprocessing. However, the method should be optimized for performance and resource usage.

## Example Usage

```python
from github import Github

g = Github("<access_token>")
repo = g.get_repo("<repo_owner>/<repo_name>")
repo.clone_to("<local_directory>")

```

This method would be particularly useful for automated processes that require the use of GitHub repositories, such as continuous integration or deployment pipelines. It would allow users to automate the process of cloning repositories without relying on external tools.

title: Does PyGitHub follow semantic versioning?
body:
The changelog for the project states it ["switched" to semantic versioning](https://pygithub.readthedocs.io/en/latest/changes.html#version-1-8-0-september-30th-2012) in version 1.8

I'm seeing a lot of new versions listing "Breaking Changes" without an actual bump to the major version.
Some example releases that mention breaking changes:
https://pygithub.readthedocs.io/en/latest/changes.html#version-1-57-november-05-2022
https://pygithub.readthedocs.io/en/latest/changes.html#version-1-55-april-26-2021

Is there a way that users can shield themselves from breaking changes excluding pinning a fixed version in their project's dependency?

title: Reworking GithubIntegration
body:
The `GithubIntegration` (Github App installations) can be used as follows:

```python
gi = GithubIntegration(app_id, private_key, ...)
ri = gi.get_repo_installation(owner, repo)
gh = gi.get_github_for_installation(ri.id, permissions)
```

Then, `gh` is a `github.Github` instance, authenticated as Github App installation `ri`.

The arguments of `Github(...)` and `GithubIntegration(...)` have to stay in sync, except for those related to authentication. A test is added to assert this.

Allows `Requester(jwt=...)` to be given a method instead of a static token string. That method is called whenever a request is made. This ensures the JWT token (which has an expiry) is always up-to-date.

A `Requester(app_auth=...)` asks `app_auth._get_access_token_func` to return a function that provides an active token. Method `_get_access_token_func` reuses a requester (the calling requester) with JWT authentication. The caching and refreshing is moved into `AppAuthentication`.

All requesters use the same values for `verify`, `retry`, `base_url`, ... as given to `GithubIntegration(...)`.

Btw., current `AppAuthentication` is better called `AppInstallationAuthentication`, as it authenticates an Github App _installation_ (app id, private key, installation id). The (app id, private key) tuple is used to authentcate as an Github App (e.g. to fetch installations), so that is better called `AppAuthentication`.

With this rework, I don't see a need for users to call `create_jwt` or `get_access_token`, they will expire anyway.

title: Fix GithubIntegration that uses expiring jwt

This does  not fix expiring JWT tokens when iterating over pages returned by `get_installations()`, or calling `get_repos()` on returned `Installations`. This will require a bigger rework.

title: Authenticating with a GitHub App not working with custom URL
body:
Hello there,

It seems like the `base_url` passed to the default constructor is not used to fetch the access token for app authentication.

Here's an example code:
```
app_id = "XXX"
app_private_key = "XXX"
installation_id = "XXX"
g = github.Github(
    base_url="https://custom-github-url.com"
    app_auth=github.AppAuthentication(
        app_id=app_id,
        private_key=app_private_key,
        installation_id=installation_id,
    ),
)
```

Whatever `base_url` is passed, the following error occurs:
`requests.exceptions.ConnectionError: HTTPSConnectionPool(host='api.github.com', port=443): Max retries exceeded with url: XXX`

As can be seen in the stack trace, the host is the one defined [here](https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/5e27c10a3140c3b9bbf71a0b71c96e71e1e3496c/github/Consts.py#L135), which is `DEFAULT_BASE_URL = "https://api.github.com"`.

I suspect the error comes from [here](https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/5e27c10a3140c3b9bbf71a0b71c96e71e1e3496c/github/Requester.py#L377). The param `base_url` is not passed to `GithubIntegration` which therefore uses the default url.

title: Move RLock initialization

title: GithubObjects are no longer serializable with `pickle`
body:
To support data exchange, being able to serialize non-JSON-serializable `GithubObject`s has been easily achieved in past with `pickle`. However, starting with v1.58, `GithubObject`s like `Repository`, `NamedUser`, etc. are no longer serializable with with `pickle`,

For example,
```py
import github
import pickle

repo = github.Github().get_repo(full_name_or_id="PyGithub/PyGithub")
pickle.dumps(repo)
```
raise the following exception:
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/joshfell/code/daedalus/tempCodeRunnerFile.python", line 15, in <module>
    pickle.dumps(repo)
  File "/usr/local/Cellar/python@3.10/3.10.9/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.10/lib/python3.10/multiprocessing/synchronize.py", line 101, in __getstate__
    context.assert_spawning(self)
  File "/usr/local/Cellar/python@3.10/3.10.9/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.10/lib/python3.10/multiprocessing/context.py", line 373, in assert_spawning
    raise RuntimeError(
RuntimeError: RLock objects should only be shared between processes through inheritance
```

The underyling `Requester` object now has an `RLock()` attribute, `__auth_lock`, which looks to be preventing this serialization.

title: Move CI to Python 3.11 release and 3.12 dev
body:
Python 3.11 has been released, 3.12 is the new dev.

title: v1.58.0 TypeError: create_jwt() got an unexpected keyword argument 'expiration'
body: The `expiration` keyword argument was removed in v1.58.0. The interface defined in GithubIntegration.pyi is no longer accurate.

title: 401 unauthorized after upgrading to 1.58.0
body:
We use `GithubIntegration.get_access_token` to authenticate and after upgrading we now get this response:

```
github.GithubException.GithubException: 401 {"message": "'Expiration time' claim ('exp') must be a numeric value representing the future time at which the assertion expires", "documentation_url": "https://docs.github.com/rest"}
```

Reverting to 1.57 solves the issue.

title: 1.58 is not compatible with AWS Lambda
body:
1.58 introduces a dependency on multiprocessing.RLock which it not compatible with AWS Lambda. multiprocessing.SemLock (used by RLock in Requester.py) will raise OSError [Errno 38] Function not implemented. This is caused by /dev/shm not being available in AWS Lamba.

I don't have a workaround and downgraded to 1.57 which works fine.

ImportError: cannot import name 'Github' from 'github' (unknown location)`

title: is it possible to get private members of the organization (e.g. for logged in session)?
body:
I ran
```
In [6]: from github import Github

In [7]: gh = Github(os.environ['GITHUB_TOKEN'])

In [8]: org = gh.get_organization('dandi')

In [9]: [m.login for m in org.get_members()]
Out[9]: ['AlmightyYakob', 'dandibot', 'satra', 'yarikoptic']
```

which listed only public, no Private despite me being logged in. https://docs.github.com/en/rest/orgs/members?apiVersion=2022-11-28 has nothing explicit on private members being filtered/could be queried besides figuring it out for a given user name https://docs.github.com/en/rest/orgs/members?apiVersion=2022-11-28#check-organization-membership-for-a-user which would defeat the purpose of asking for a list of members.

As an example, for a certain organization and it's repos, I ran the script and it gave me a 502 error, but then a few minutes later it ran as intended and gave me the correct results.

Anyone else facing this issue?

Thanks for the help!

title: Retry retryable 403 (rate limit)
body:
GitHub response with rate limit errors (403 Forbidden) when request occur too frequently. While they can be mitigated by throttling request rate (see #1989), they can still occur.

Not all 403 errors are retry-able (e.g. access forbidden if not authenticated), so retrying based on status code (403) only would be a bad idea. The `urllib3.util.retry.Retry` interface does not allow for checking the response message or body content, only response code: urllib3/urllib3#2500

This PR introduces a bespoke PyGithub retry class that is able to determine whether to retry based on the response content. With that, 403 responses that refer to `RateLimitExceeded` are retried, other 403 responses are not retried. The base `Retry` implementation respects Retry-After headers if they exist.

Primary rate limit errors are retried after the primary rate reset occurs, secondary rate limit errors are retried after 60 seconds (configurable).

Log for a primary error rate limit:
```
2022-12-16 13:56:47 +0000 - urllib3.connectionpool - DEBUG - https://api.github.com:443 "GET /repositories/290227969/commits/71ca27c4a9d74fa7ec2898304ee75909e4a57124/check-runs?per_page=1&page=150 HTTP/1.1" 403 None
2022-12-16 13:56:47 +0000 - github.GithubRetry -  INFO - Request GET /repositories/290227969/commits/71ca27c4a9d74fa7ec2898304ee75909e4a57124/check-runs?per_page=1&page=150 failed with 403: Forbidden
2022-12-16 13:56:47 +0000 - github.GithubRetry - DEBUG - Response body indicates retry-able primary rate limit error: API rate limit exceeded for installation ID 5425010.
2022-12-16 13:56:47 +0000 - urllib3.util.retry - DEBUG - Incremented Retry for (url='/repositories/290227969/commits/71ca27c4a9d74fa7ec2898304ee75909e4a57124/check-runs?per_page=1&page=150'): GithubRetry(total=9, connect=None, read=None, redirect=None, status=None)
2022-12-16 13:56:47 +0000 - github.GithubRetry - DEBUG - Reset occurs in 0:24:24.940607 (1671200472 / 2022-12-16 14:21:12)
2022-12-16 13:56:47 +0000 - github.GithubRetry - INFO - Setting next backoff to 1465.940607s
2022-12-16 14:21:13 +0000 - urllib3.connectionpool - DEBUG - Retry: /repositories/290227969/commits/71ca27c4a9d74fa7ec2898304ee75909e4a57124/check-runs?per_page=1&page=150
2022-12-16 14:21:13 +0000 - urllib3.connectionpool - DEBUG - Resetting dropped connection: api.github.com
2022-12-16 14:21:13 +0000 - urllib3.connectionpool - DEBUG - https://api.github.com:443 "GET /repositories/290227969/commits/71ca27c4a9d74fa7ec2898304ee75909e4a57124/check-runs?per_page=1&page=150 HTTP/1.1" 200 None
2022-12-16 14:21:13 +0000 - github.Requester - DEBUG - GET https://api.github.com/repositories/290227969/commits/71ca27c4a9d74fa7ec2898304ee75909e4a57124/check-runs?per_page=1&page=150 {'Accept': 'application/vnd.github.v3+json', 'Authorization': 'token (oauth token removed)', 'User-Agent': 'PyGithub/Python'} None ==> 200
```


Log for a secondary error rate limit:
```
2022-12-17 09:48:56 +0000 - urllib3.connectionpool - DEBUG - https://api.github.com:443 "GET /search/issues?q=type%3Apr+repo%3A%22EnricoMi%2Fpublish-unit-test-result-action%22+df23eea893bc760a02ff52d63d9ce4c6a06c381b&per_page=10 HTTP/1.1" 403 None
2022-12-17 09:48:56 +0000 - github.GithubRetry -  INFO - Request GET /search/issues?q=type%3Apr+repo%3A%22EnricoMi%2Fpublish-unit-test-result-action%22+df23eea893bc760a02ff52d63d9ce4c6a06c381b&per_page=10 failed with 403: Forbidden
2022-12-17 09:48:56 +0000 - github.GithubRetry - DEBUG - Response body indicates retry-able secondary rate limit error: You have exceeded a secondary rate limit. Please wait a few minutes before you try again.
2022-12-17 09:48:56 +0000 - urllib3.util.retry - DEBUG - Incremented Retry for (url='/search/issues?q=type%3Apr+repo%3A%22EnricoMi%2Fpublish-unit-test-result-action%22+df23eea893bc760a02ff52d63d9ce4c6a06c381b&per_page=10'): GithubRetry(total=8, connect=None, read=None, redirect=None, status=None)

2022-12-17 09:49:56 +0000 - urllib3.connectionpool - DEBUG - Retry: /search/issues?q=type%3Apr+repo%3A%22EnricoMi%2Fpublish-unit-test-result-action%22+df23eea893bc760a02ff52d63d9ce4c6a06c381b&per_page=10
2022-12-17 09:49:56 +0000 - urllib3.connectionpool - DEBUG - https://api.github.com:443 "GET /search/issues?q=type%3Apr+repo%3A%22EnricoMi%2Fpublish-unit-test-result-action%22+df23eea893bc760a02ff52d63d9ce4c6a06c381b&per_page=10 HTTP/1.1" 200 None

title: 404 happens when invoke create_pull
body:
**How to reproduce**

1. Add a python script file with following codes 
```
from github import Github
import sys

g = Github("username", "password")
echo = g.get_repo("liferay-echo/liferay-portal")
failurePR = echo.get_pull(int(sys.argv[1]))

brianchan = g.get_repo("Tim-Cao/liferay-portal")

head = str(failurePR.head.user.login) + ":" + str(failurePR.head.ref)

body = '''
This is only for master.

@''' + str(failurePR.user.login)

comments = '''
In order to not clog up ci resources, I'm sending the PR directly. Failure cases are unrelated to changes in this PR.

See ''' + str(failurePR.html_url)

pr = brianchan.create_pull(title=failurePR.title, body=body, head=head, base="master")
pr.create_issue_comment("ci:reopen")
pr.create_issue_comment(comments)
```
2.  Run script python3 fileName 10593

**Actual Results**
The following error is thrown.
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/liferay/Downloads/manualForward.py", line 31, in <module>

title: `create_git_release` lacks the `generate_release_notes` parameter
body: [`create_git_release`](https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/master/github/Repository.py#:~:text=def%20create_git_release) lacks the `generate_release_notes` parameter specified in [GitHub API reference](https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/master/github/Repository.py#:~:text=def%20create_git_release). Since it's common to create a release with autogenerated release notes, adding the boolean parameter to `create_git_release` function seems to be a meaningful life improvement for PyGithub users (We want to use it ourselves in one project).

title: feat: add allow_forking to Repository
body:
Closes #2310.

based on https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/pull/2310
but up to date and with passing tests

Adds to the allow_forking attribute to a Repository: https://docs.github.com/en/rest/repos/repos#update-a-repository

    allow_forking boolean
    Either true to allow private forks, or false to prevent private forks.

This attribute can be modified via edit (on a private repository):

```
>>> g.get_repo("<test repo>").allow_forking
True
>>> g.get_repo("<test repo>").edit(allow_forking=False)
>>> g.get_repo("<test repo>").allow_forking
False
>>> g.get_repo("<test repo>").edit(allow_forking=True)
>>> g.get_repo("<test repo>").allow_forking
True
```

title: Flake8 pre-commit dependency has moved
body:
Flake8 has moved to [GitHub](https://github.com/PyCQA/flake8) and this breaks the pre-commit hook using the now [404 Gitlab URL](https://gitlab.com/PyCQA/flake8).

Running `tox -e lint` locally gives an error like the following:

```
[INFO] Initializing environment for https://gitlab.com/pycqa/flake8.
An unexpected error has occurred: CalledProcessError: command: ('/thisiswhereyourbinis/bin/git', 'fetch', 'origin', '--tags')
return code: 128
expected return code: 0
stdout: (none)
stderr:
    remote: The project you were looking for could not be found or you don't have permission to view it.
    fatal: repository 'https://gitlab.com/pycqa/flake8.git/' not found

Check the log at /yourcacheplace/pre-commit/pre-commit.log
ERROR: InvocationError for command /yourProjectPath/PyGithub/.tox/lint/bin/pre-commit run --all-files --show-diff-on-failure (exited with code 3)
_________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________ summary __________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________
ERROR:   lint: commands failed
```

CI pipelines are breaking too with the following error:

```
[INFO] Initializing environment for https://gitlab.com/pycqa/flake8.
  An unexpected error has occurred: CalledProcessError: command: ('/usr/bin/git', 'fetch', 'origin', '--tags')
  return code: 128
  expected return code: 0
  stdout: (none)
  stderr:
      fatal: could not read Username for 'https://gitlab.com/': No such device or address
      
  Check the log at /home/runner/.cache/pre-commit/pre-commit.log
  Error: ERROR: InvocationError for command /home/runner/work/PyGithub/PyGithub/.tox/lint/bin/pre-commit run --all-files --show-diff-on-failure (exited with code 3)
py38 create: /home/runner/work/PyGithub/PyGithub/.tox/py38
```



It's a quick fix, easier than creating this issue, but I'm creating it because it's the first place I look for problems and others might benefit from it. Will submit PR in a minute.

title: RequiredPullRequestReviews not returning all values.
body:
When using pyGithub I seem to not get all attributes from RequiredPullRequestReviews class

```
from github import Github 
from simple_term_menu import TerminalMenu
g = Github(
    "<TOKEN>") 

def menus(options,title):
    terminal_menu = TerminalMenu(options, title=title)
    menu_entry_index = terminal_menu.show()
    print(f"You have selected {options[menu_entry_index]}!")
    return(options[menu_entry_index])


def get_user_orgs():
    orgs = []
    for org in user.get_orgs():
        orgs.append(org.login)
    return orgs

def get_org_repos(organization):
    repos = []
    for repo in g.get_organization(organization).get_repos():
        repos.append(repo.name)
    return repos
# def get_repo_
    
def main():
    org_select = menus(get_user_orgs(), "Please select an Org:")
    repo_select = menus(get_org_repos(org_select), "Plesae select a repository:")    
    
    repo =g.get_repo(f"{org_select}/{repo_select}")
    branch = repo.get_branch("main")
    print(branch.get_protection().required_pull_request_reviews)
    

    
    
if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
```
    
Results in 
 ```
python3 github_branch_fixer.py
You have selected <org>!
You have selected <repo>!
RequiredPullRequestReviews(url="https://api.github.com/repos/<org>/<repo>/branches/main/protection/required_pull_request_reviews", require_code_owner_reviews=False, dismiss_stale_reviews=True) 
```
Running the curl equivalent 

```curl \
  -H "Accept: application/vnd.github+json" \
  -H "Authorization: Bearer <TOKEN>" \
  https://api.github.com/repos/<org>/<repo>/branches/main/protection/required_pull_request_reviews
{
  "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/<org>/<repo>/branches/main/protection/required_pull_request_reviews",
  "dismiss_stale_reviews": true,
  "require_code_owner_reviews": false,
  "require_last_push_approval": true,

}
```

Python 3.10.8

title: fix: update GithubIntegration.get_access_token

The method is in need for some updating. The current body parameter, `user_id` is not listed anywhere within the Github specification.

What is [listed](https://docs.github.com/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/rest/apps/apps#create-an-installation-access-token-for-an-app), however, are three body parameters to pass in order to scope the access token to the minimum privileges it requires.

title: Update sphinx-rtd-theme requirement from <1.1 to <1.2
body:
Updates the requirements on [sphinx-rtd-theme](https://github.com/readthedocs/sphinx_rtd_theme) to permit the latest version.
Changelog

Sourced from sphinx-rtd-theme's changelog.

1.1.1

Fixes

  • Fix wrapping bug on cross references (#1368)

.. _release-1.1.0:

1.1.0

Dependency Changes

Many documentation projects depend on sphinx-rtd-theme without specifying a version of the theme (unpinned) while also depending on unpinned versions of Sphinx. The latest version of sphinx-rtd-theme ideally always supports the latest version of Sphinx, but this is now guaranteed.

This release adds upper bounds to direct dependencies Sphinx and docutils which will safeguard from mixing with possibly incompatible future versions of Sphinx & docutils.

  • Sphinx versions supported: 1.6 to 5.2.x
  • Sphinx<6 (#1332)
  • docutils<0.18 (unchanged, but will be bumped in an upcoming release)

Features

  • Nicer styles for (#967)
  • New styling for breadcrumbs (#1073)

Fixes

  • Suffixes in Sphinx version caused build errors (#1345)
  • Table cells with multiple paragraphs gets wrong formatting (#289)
  • Definition lists rendered wrongly in api docs (#1052)
  • Citation not styled properly (#1078)
  • Long URLs did not wrap (#1193)

Minor Changes

  • Sphinx 5.2 added to test matrix (#1348)
  • Python 3.10 added to test matrix (#1334)
  • Supplemental Docker setup for development (#1319)
  • Most of setup.py migrated to setup.cfg (#1116)
  • Jinja2 context variable sphinx_version_info is now (major, minor, -1), the patch component is always -1. Reason: It's complicated. (#1345)

title: Organization exists but still getting Unknown Object Error 404
body:
Hi guys

I am trying to get data about a few repositories through the following method:

```
gh = Github(TOKEN)
    
org = gh.get_organization('0xMonero')
```

If I run the above code on any other organization, I get a valid result. But running the above code with the `0xMonero` organization, I get the following error:

`UnknownObjectException: 404 {"message": "Not Found", "documentation_url": "https://docs.github.com/rest"}`

Going to the actual URL of the organization (https://github.com/0xMonero), I can see that it indeed is a valid public organization, so why is it throwing an error?

Or does the pygithub API only return results for the past 1 year? Because that then makes sense because the organization has not activity for the past 2 years.

Thanks for your help!

title: Fix typo in blame ignore revs
Fix/types for repo topic team
body:
This PR fixes type definitions for:

* Repository
* Team
* Topic

This was prompted by `mypy` failing on some of my code, because types for `Repository.is_template()` were missing.

The missing/incorrect types were found by running (for example):

```shell
python -m mypy.stubtest github.Repository
```

and going through each result manually.

If there's a more automated way to do this, I'd be keen to hear about it!

FWIW there are a large number of types that need a bit of attention. I was thinking of raising a PR to run `mypy.stubtest` in CI, but there are a lot of fixes to make before that could run green, so I thought it would be easier to review / merge these fixes in chunks.

title: Require pyjwt>=2.4.0 to avoid CVE-2022-29217
body:
Fixes https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/issues/2260.

Avoid  CVE-2022-29217 by requiring pyjwt>=2.4.0.

PyGithub requires `pyjwt>=2.0`, so there's nothing to stop end users updating, and if they do a fresh install they'll get a newer version.

But it's a good idea to require at least the fixed 2.4.0 as a minimum version too.

title: PyGithub project status ?
body:
Hello @adamtheturtle, @jacquev6, @JPWKU, @sfdye

What is the current status of the PyGithub project ?

The project seems quite used and appreciated (5.5k stars). However, the most recent commit in the project dates back from 2021, one year ago. In the meantime, the Github REST API evolves and several users provided pull requests. 50 of them are waiting for integration.

The community seems active. I recently asked a question about a missing feature (#2313) and a user, @lexa, immediately provided a pull request with the missing feature (#2319).

It is a pity that 50 pull requests, probably mostly improvements, are queuing for one year. In the meantime, users doing `pip install PyGithub` (as I did a couple of weeks ago) do not benefit from them. How could we unblock the situation, let the waiting PR's being reviewed and integrated and let PyPI get updated with a bright new version?

Thanks all,

title: feat: add allow_forking to Repository
body:
Adds to the `allow_forking` attribute to a `Repository`: https://docs.github.com/en/rest/repos/repos#update-a-repository
> **allow_forking** boolean
> Either true to allow private forks, or false to prevent private forks.

This attribute can be modified via `edit` (on a private repository):
```py
>>> g.get_repo("<test repo>").allow_forking
True
>>> g.get_repo("<test repo>").edit(allow_forking=False)
>>> g.get_repo("<test repo>").allow_forking
False
>>> g.get_repo("<test repo>").edit(allow_forking=True)
>>> g.get_repo("<test repo>").allow_forking
True
```

title: [Bug fix] - Remove references to `unicode` type, no longer supported in Python3
body: The `unicode` type is no longer supported by Python3, and has been absorbed into the `str` type. Using the `unicode` type in Python3 will cause errors, so I removed all references to this type

title: [WorkflowRun] - Add missing attributes (`run_started_at` & `run_attempt`), remove deprecated `unicode` type
body:
As per the title, this PR adds the `run_started_at` and `run_attempt` attributes to the WorkflowRun class, following the Github API reference page: https://docs.github.com/en/rest/actions/workflow-runs#get-a-workflow-run .

In addition, I removed the `unicode` type since it is no longer supported by Python3, and has been absorbed into the `str` type. Using the `unicode` type in Python3 will cause errors, so I removed all references to this type.

This PR is consolidating the changes from PR #2274 , as recommended by @marcorosa .

title: Merge does not squash correctly
body:
Dear all,
in using the `merge` function I noticed that, even when the only allowed possibility is `squash and merge`, the commits do not get squashed automatically. Here is a minimal code to reproduce my results:

```
from github import Github
import os

GITHUB_TOKEN = os.getenv("GITHUB_TOKEN")


def create_pr_and_merge():
    git = Github(login_or_token=GITHUB_TOKEN)
    repository = git.get_repo("my-repo")
    branch = "test-branch"

    repository.create_file(message="Adding file",
                           path="my_file.py",
                           branch=branch,
                           content="# Some interesting content")

    repository.create_pull(title="Ticket nr. XXX",
                           body="",
                           head=branch,
                           base="master")

    repository.merge(base="master",
                     head=branch,
                     commit_message="Bug fix")


if __name__ == "__main__":
    create_pr_and_merge()
```

Given the automatic squash, I would expect to see only one commit message, i.e. "Ticket nr. XXX". Instead, I see both the latter and "Adding file", which is undesired behavior. Any ideas why this is the case?

title: Bump actions/setup-python from 2 to 4
body:
Bumps [actions/setup-python](https://github.com/actions/setup-python) from 2 to 4.
Release notes

Sourced from actions/setup-python's releases.

v4.0.0

What's Changed

  • Support for python-version-file input: #336

Example of usage:

- uses: actions/setup-python@v4
  with:
    python-version-file: '.python-version' # Read python version from a file
- run: python my_script.py

There is no default python version for this setup-python major version, the action requires to specify either python-version input or python-version-file input. If the python-version input is not specified the action will try to read required version from file from python-version-file input.

  • Use pypyX.Y for PyPy python-version input: #349

Example of usage:

- uses: actions/setup-python@v4
  with:
    python-version: 'pypy3.9' # pypy-X.Y kept for backward compatibility
- run: python my_script.py

  • RUNNER_TOOL_CACHE environment variable is equal AGENT_TOOLSDIRECTORY: #338

  • Bugfix: create missing pypyX.Y symlinks: #347

  • PKG_CONFIG_PATH environment variable: #400

  • Added python-path output: #405 python-path output contains Python executable path.

  • Updated zeit/ncc to vercel/ncc package: #393

  • Bugfix: fixed output for prerelease version of poetry: #409

  • Made pythonLocation environment variable consistent for Python and PyPy: #418

  • Bugfix for 3.x-dev syntax: #417

  • Other improvements: #318 #396 #384 #387 #388

Update actions/cache version to 2.0.2

In scope of this release we updated actions/cache package as the new version contains fixes related to GHES 3.5 (actions/setup-python#382)

Add "cache-hit" output and fix "python-version" output for PyPy

This release introduces new output cache-hit (actions/setup-python#373) and fix python-version output for PyPy (actions/setup-python#365)

The cache-hit output contains boolean value indicating that an exact match was found for the key. It shows that the action uses already existing cache or not. The output is available only if cache is enabled.

... (truncated)

title: Update sphinx requirement from <3 to <6
body:
Updates the requirements on [sphinx](https://github.com/sphinx-doc/sphinx) to permit the latest version.
Changelog

Sourced from sphinx's changelog.

Release 5.0.0 (released May 30, 2022)

Dependencies

5.0.0 b1

  • #10164: Support Docutils 0.18_. Patch by Adam Turner.

.. _Docutils 0.18: https://docutils.sourceforge.io/RELEASE-NOTES.html#release-0-18-2021-10-26

Incompatible changes

5.0.0 b1

  • #10031: autosummary: sphinx.ext.autosummary.import_by_name() now raises ImportExceptionGroup instead of ImportError when it failed to import target object. Please handle the exception if your extension uses the function to import Python object. As a workaround, you can disable the behavior via grouped_exception=False keyword argument until v7.0.
  • #9962: texinfo: Customizing styles of emphasized text via @definfoenclose command was not supported because the command was deprecated since texinfo 6.8
  • #2068: :confval:intersphinx_disabled_reftypes has changed default value from an empty list to ['std:doc'] as avoid too surprising silent intersphinx resolutions. To migrate: either add an explicit inventory name to the references intersphinx should resolve, or explicitly set the value of this configuration variable to an empty list.
  • #10197: html theme: Reduce body_min_width setting in basic theme to 360px
  • #9999: LaTeX: separate terms from their definitions by a CR (refs: #9985)
  • #10062: Change the default language to 'en' if any language is not set in conf.py

5.0.0 final

  • #10474: :confval:language does not accept None as it value. The default value of language becomes to 'en' now.

Deprecated

5.0.0 b1

  • #10028: jQuery and underscore.js will no longer be automatically injected into themes from Sphinx 6.0. If you develop a theme or extension that uses the jQuery, $, or $u global objects, you need to update your JavaScript or use the mitigation below.

title: Export PaginatedList and NotSet from `github`
body: The rest of the `[Utilities](https://pygithub.readthedocs.io/en/latest/utilities.html#default-argument)` are accessible from the github package - eg. `github.InputGitAuthor`. This exposes PaginatedList and NotSetType in a similar fashion, so that they can be used in python type hints.

title: Add code scanning alerts
body:
Github provides an option to obtain code scanning alerts of the code in a repository as part of the API, see https://docs.github.com/en/rest/reference/code-scanning#list-code-scanning-alerts-for-a-repository.
This part of the API was not yet supported by PyGithub.

Added a method to the Repository class to obtain the codescan alerts.
Added classes to hold to the information returned.

title: Add support for environments
body:
[Environments](https://docs.github.com/en/actions/deployment/targeting-different-environments/using-environments-for-deployment) are a feature in Github that allows setting up deployment rules, like manual approval, per repository. Because they can only be configured per repository, this makes automating their management particularly important for many-repository micro-service application. This PR adds support for getting, creating, updating and deleting environments as documented [here](https://docs.github.com/en/rest/deployments/environments).

This partially implements the features requested by [issue 2067](https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/issues/2067) (environments, but not environment secrets).

title: Bump actions/setup-python from 2 to 3.1.0
body:
Bumps [actions/setup-python](https://github.com/actions/setup-python) from 2 to 3.1.0.
Release notes

Sourced from actions/setup-python's releases.

Support caching poetry dependencies and caching on GHES 3.5

  • In the scope of this release, we added support for caching from GHES 3.5 and fixed the download issue for files > 2GB during restore.
  • Caching poetry dependencies
steps:
- uses: actions/checkout@v3
- name: Install poetry
  run: pipx install poetry
- uses: actions/setup-python@v3
  with:
    python-version: '3.9'
    cache: 'poetry'
- run: poetry install
- run: poetry run pytest

v3.0.0

What's Changed

  • Update default runtime to node16 (actions/setup-python#340)
  • Update package-lock.json file version to 2, @types/node to 16.11.25 and typescript to 4.2.3 (actions/setup-python#341)
  • Remove legacy pypy2 and pypy3 keywords (actions/setup-python#342)

Breaking Changes

With the update to Node 16, all scripts will now be run with Node 16 rather than Node 12.

This new major release removes support of legacy pypy2 and pypy3 keywords. Please use more specific and flexible syntax to specify a PyPy version:

jobs:
  build:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    strategy:
      matrix:
        python-version:
        - 'pypy-2.7' # the latest available version of PyPy that supports Python 2.7
        - 'pypy-3.8' # the latest available version of PyPy that supports Python 3.8
        - 'pypy-3.8-v7.3.8' # Python 3.8 and PyPy 7.3.8
    steps:
    - uses: actions/checkout@v2
    - uses: actions/setup-python@v3
      with:
        python-version: ${{ matrix.python-version }}

See more usage examples in the documentation

Update primary and restore keys for pip

In scope of this release we include a version of python in restore and primary cache keys for pip. Besides, we add temporary fix for Windows caching issue, that the pip cache dir command returns non zero exit code or writes to stderr. Moreover we updated node-fetch dependency.

Update actions/cache version to 1.0.8

We have updated actions/cache dependency version to 1.0.8 to support 10GB cache upload

Support caching dependencies

title: How do I correct issues that do not contain pull requests?
body:
I want to collect issues that do not contain pull requests with GitHub API v3. 
However, the get_issue method, which can be used to collect issues, returns issues that contain pull requests(e.g., #2010).

How do I distinguish between issues and pull requests?

I am thinking of several ways such as the following code:
```
github = Github("token")
repo = github.get_repo(full_name_or_id="reponame")
issue = repo.get_issue(issue_number)

if issue.pullrequest == None:
    # this issue is a true issue!
else: # issue.pullrequest != None
    # this issue actually is a pull request!
```
Does this code work well?

Breaking Changes

With the update to Node 16, all scripts will now be run with Node 16 rather than Node 12.

This new major release removes support of legacy pypy2 and pypy3 keywords. Please use more specific and flexible syntax to specify a PyPy version:

jobs:
  build:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    strategy:
      matrix:

See more usage examples in the documentation

Update primary and restore keys for pip

In scope of this release we include a version of python in restore and primary cache keys for pip. Besides, we add temporary fix for Windows caching issue, that the pip cache dir command returns non zero exit code or writes to stderr. Moreover we updated node-fetch dependency.

Update actions/cache version to 1.0.8

We have updated actions/cache dependency version to 1.0.8 to support 10GB cache upload

Support caching dependencies

This release introduces dependency caching support (actions/setup-python#266)

Caching dependencies.

The action has a built-in functionality for caching and restoring pip/pipenv dependencies. The cache input is optional, and caching is turned off by default.

Besides, this release introduces dependency caching support for mono repos and repositories with complex structure.

By default, the action searches for the dependency file (requirements.txt for pip or Pipfile.lock for pipenv) in the whole repository. Use the cache-dependency-path input for cases when you want to override current behaviour and use different file for hash generation (for example requirements-dev.txt). This input supports wildcards or a list of file names for caching multiple dependencies.

Caching pip dependencies:

steps:
- uses: actions/checkout@v2
- uses: actions/setup-python@v2
  with:
    python-version: '3.9'

title: Please expose triage and maintain permissions for github.Repository.Repository.get_collaborator_permission
body:
Hi there, It seems like **github.Repository.Repository.get_collaborator_permission** exposes only **admin,write and read** permissions and treats `maintain` as `write` and `triage` as `read`. Is it possible to add maintain and triage permissions as well to that API call response?

Thank you in advance.

title: github.GithubException.UnknownObjectException: 404 {"message": "Not Found"
body:
I wrote the following code that updates a file on GitHub, it is still working fine on my windows pc but is giving an error if I do the same thing on google cloud f1 micro instance running ubuntu 18.04 LTS. How do I fix this? This is only happening for updating the files on the repo. If I want to create a new repo then it is working fine on both window and gcp linux.

I thought it was due to permissions of personal access tokens but it is not, updating the file from my pc with the same code works fine, but doing the same thing on gcp is returning the following error.

Here's the error
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "gitup.py", line 48, in <module>
    updateRepo("testttt", "api.json", "update api.json")
  File "gitup.py", line 38, in updateRepo
    fileContents = repo.get_contents("/home/manideeppatnam123/crypto-whales-api/api.json", ref="master")
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/dist-packages/github/Repository.py", line 1792, in get_contents
    parameters=url_parameters,
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/dist-packages/github/Requester.py", line 355, in requestJsonAndCheck
    verb, url, parameters, headers, input, self.__customConnection(url)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/dist-packages/github/Requester.py", line 378, in __check
    raise self.__createException(status, responseHeaders, output)
github.GithubException.UnknownObjectException: 404 {"message": "Not Found", "documentation_url": "https://docs.github.com/rest/reference/repos#get-repository-content"}
```




and here's the code
```
from github import Github

def loginToGitHub():
    g = Github("personal-access-token-redacted")
    print("--- Login successful")

    return g

def updateRepo(repoName, fileName, commitMessage):
    g = loginToGitHub()

    user = g.get_user()

    repo = g.get_repo(f"{user.login}/{repoName}")

    fileContents = repo.get_contents(f"./{fileName}")

    f = open(fileName, "r")
    newContent = f.read()
    f.close()

    repo.update_file(fileContents.path, commitMessage, newContent, fileContents.sha)
    print("--- File updated successfully")


#here testttt is the repo name, api.json is the file that I'm updating
updateRepo("testttt", "api.json", "update api.json")
```

any help would be appreciated. Thanks!

title: Support `/orgs/{org}/audit-log` endpoint

title: Make Requester.__createException robust against missing message and body
body:
This adds tests for `Requester.__createException` while making this method robust against `output` missing `"message"` and `output = None` for all status.

Note: This simplifies logic while making `BadCredentialsException`, `BadUserAgentException` and `UnknownObjectException` case-insensitive to the message.

Fixes #1399 and #2158.

Note: Add that extra message from #2127 to `tests.Requester.testShouldCreateRateLimitExceededException`, either in that PR or here, whatever gets merged last.

title: bypass pr review user team
body:
Currently PyGithub cannot set branch protection to allow bypass pull request review users or teams. This is done against the GitHub API with a PUT @ [/repos/{owner}/{repo}/branches/{branch}/protection](https://docs.github.com/en/rest/reference/branches#update-branch-protection), which `Branch.edit_protection()` already hits. I've added new parameters to that method and `Branch.edit_required_pull_request_reviews()` following existing patterns that result in including a `bypass_pull_request_reviews` object in the payload.

I am having trouble generating the ReplayData for a new test because of an auth issue, but have curated it manually to allow the test to pass. I also did some additional local testing with a project that uses PyGithub.

- support to set bypass pr review users or teams
- manually created replay data

title: Throttle requests to mitigate RateLimitExceededExceptions
body:
This introduces a throttling of requests to the Github REST API (1s for writes, 0.25s for reads, configurable) to mitigate secondary rate limit errors and comply with Github's  best practices: https://docs.github.com/en/rest/guides/best-practices-for-integrators?apiVersion=2022-11-28#dealing-with-secondary-rate-limits

It defines a minimum time span between consecutive requests to the GitHub API, both caused by user code calling into the PyGithub API and called by PyGithub internally (e.g. user code iterating over a paginated list). This is achieved by hooking into the lowest possible method that is used to send all requests to GitHub API: `Requester.__requestRaw`.

For each verb the timestamp of the last request (when `__requestRaw` returned) is recorded and used before the next request to compute the time that has to be waited before the request is issued. It then calls into `time.sleep()` to respect the minimum time span.

It distinguishes between the time between any request and the time between writes. GitHub expects at least one second between writing requests (e.g. `POST`): https://docs.github.com/en/rest/guides/best-practices-for-integrators#dealing-with-secondary-rate-limits

This code is being used in [EnricoMi/publish-unit-test-result-action](https://github.com/EnricoMi/publish-unit-test-result-action/blob/b9e81bf6bfe9982d9a469f2a10e660633a0b6b85/python/publish_test_results.py#L175-L198) and runs thousands of times each day.

Here is an example log:
```
2022-10-25 07:49:05 - sleeping 0.1404111385345459s before next GitHub request
2022-10-25 07:49:05 - GitHub request: POST /repos/EnricoMi/publish-unit-test-result-action/check-runs
2022-10-25 07:49:06 - sleeping 1.9985311031341553s before next GitHub request
2022-10-25 07:49:08 - GitHub request: PATCH /repos/EnricoMi/publish-unit-test-result-action/check-runs/9087539036
```

This fixes #1989.

body:
I've been struggling to find the best way to use Python to programmatically upload a .ipa file, and I figured this library would be absolutely perfect. However, I couldn't find any examples of other people using the PyGithub releases-related methods so I am not entirely sure if I am using it correctly.

Here's the error traceback:
```
Exception has occurred: ConnectionError
('Connection aborted.', ConnectionResetError(10054, 'An existing connection was forcibly closed by the remote host', None, 10054, None))

During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:

```

Here's the code snippet I am currently using to upload:
```py
g = Github(os.getenv("GITHUB_TOKEN"))
g_repo = g.get_repo(321891219)
g_release = g_repo.get_latest_release()
with open(ipa_path, "rb") as file:

For reference, `ipa_path` is a Path (pathlib) object that looks something like this: `WindowsPath('C:/Users/noah/AppData/Local/Temp/tmpd5jl9qo9/temp2.zip')`

The file in question is zip file by nature, but is technically an IPA (Apple software package). If it matters, the basename of the file and the name supplied to the upload method are not the same, but I tested this theory and it didn't seem to matter.
